title: RIOT going ham with the Player Bans is a big mistake.
body: All because there are snowflakes that are crying about being told to ward and having their e-feelings hurt when there is a mute button not being used. Keep it up, you won't have a player base at all. If your goal is to make this game for a target age of 12 and under, you're off to a great start Riot.

replies.body:
You know every time I see the term "special snowflake" used it is almost always by people who that term applies to most as they can't stand actually being held accountable for their behavior in a video game. Like Jamaree said when people claim that they were banned for stuff like "please ward here" almost always their chat logs show them being a verbally abusive jerk throughout the game. Yes there's a mute button but that's meant to be a band-aid solution at most and does not excuse the poor behavior that led to one using the mute button in the first place.

Bottom line: If you can't interact with others in a mature and respectful manner then this is not the game for you.

> [{quoted}](name=LordofStone,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=tlBOeeMG,comment-id=00060000,timestamp=2018-03-13T04:00:34.005+0000)
>
> I agree, this is why I quit. I enjoy freedom of speech from pussies.

Except that Freedom of Speech only applies to the government, preventing them from making laws limiting free speech. What it does NOT do is provide freedom of consequence, nor does it apply to privately owned businesses such as Riot Games. From [Ulanopo's Knowledge Base](http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=4086541&page=1#post43465469): 

>**"Freedom of Speech!!!!!"**

>Doesn't apply. No really. If we're talking about American law, the First Amendment only applies to the government making laws that prohibit speech and, even then, freedom of speech isn't absolute. For example, you can't incite a riot, plan to kill the president or yell fire in a crowded theater.

>Also, there's nothing in the First Amendment that protects you from the consequences of your speech. People are fired all the time for making derogatory comments about their employer. My workplace, for example, has a social media policy that says that I can be terminated for badmouthing the company. They don't ask for passwords and access as some companies have been known to do, but it wouldn't be all that difficult to find me on the internet, knowing my real name, phone number and address.

People who quit don't post on forums. Your half-hearted attempt don't fool anyone nor will it ever change anything. So stop lying to the board and most of all stop lying to yourself. You'll start playing again after your 14-day ban. Till then, you'll keep up with all the updates and post on the forums. Then you just might quit when your permaban happens, but first, you'll complain for the next few days on the forums, try to start some poll on the board just to follow up like the rest of the many and many people before you who got permabanned. Then you'll either make a new account or whatever. 

The thing is, it doesn't matter if you quit or not because that whole idea to the rest of League's community is absolutely irrelevant to them. The only thing relevant to this community is that you're in check with your attitude and you do your best. **The only thing you're here to do and meant to do in this game. Believe it or not, is meant to have fun and have a mutual understanding of respect for other players.**
Other than that, nothing else exists. 

Riot wants the same thing, but they also want one more thing. They want you to follow the ToU that you agreed to before you even downloaded this game. But if you can't, then they'll simply erase your account and move on with the community who does care about the ToU and the game they're part of. They want players who understand what this game is about and what it was made for. You're either part of the game or you're part of the problem. Riot gets rid of the problem and the community supports them for it.

> 
> Bottom line: If you can't interact with others in a mature and respectful manner then this is not the game for you.

To be fair, not everyone is "nice" in real life either. Do you think my boss at work cares if he hurt my feelings? I can assure you that he does not. Trash talking is a part of life, there are always people that won't like other people. Being a prick to every person in every game, I do think that's inappropriate behavior as well as the usual "hate language" such as racism, or other harassment. 

Generally though, if a player sees something really stupid and calls it out.. I truly feel like it's overkill to chat restrict or even ban someone (unless they are really overdoing it). If someone tells me I'm retarded chasing an enemy half way across the map and I die attempting to 1v5 when I don't even have a huge lead, I'll accept that. Sure, it hurts my feelings and probably doesn't need to be said, but I messed up and made that person feel that way. To me they have a right to express themselves (as long as they aren't being excessive about it).

Granted, it isn't my game and I don't make the rules here but I think Riot usually is too harsh when punishing players. Even in the scenario where some player truly is a (verbal) menace to the player base, why permanently ban that player? Chat restrict them, if they continue the behavior, permanently silence their account so that the server doesn't accept messages they send in the chat. Some people are not and cannot, be nice individuals. To me it's not right to exile them from a form of entertainment. Unless someone is intentionally feeding, or ruining games for other players on purpose, I really think the idea of "permanently banning" an account is unjustified and actually fairly unintelligent for a company such as Riot Games.

People are generally only permabanned for poor behavior after they've be given and blown multiple chances to improve their behavior for the better. As for the idea that Riot should just perma-mute accounts instead of permabanning them, Riot tried that before and it didn't work. From [Riot Tantram:](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/wsObUaFj-if-tyler1?comment=00010001000000000000) 

> It really breaks down into two categories.
> 
> 1.) Helping players reform
> 2.) Shielding others from the behavior, at a cost.
> 
> We used to issue chat restrictions that essentially scaled indefinitely. 
> 
> We were able to determine that after a certain point the penalty no longer helped with reform. The 10-game and 25-game counts for chat restrictions are based on data that they were both light enough, and felt strict enough to encourage people to understand their behavior is unacceptable in game and change it.
> 
> We also saw that the players in this 'large restriction' category defaulted to gameplay altering means of harassing their team. It caused an increase in feeding and trolling.
> 
> The sample size of this population and time frame is huge. Essentially the time spanning from the introduction of chat restrictions to the introduction of IFS.
> 
> So my question for you is, would you rather have more feeders and less negative chat?

If someone isn't gonna interact with others in a mature and respectful manner despite getting multiple chances to do so then why shouldn't they be removed from the community?

I believe the "method" is at fault here. Having a limited number of messages in a game is rage inducing in itself. Have you ever been chat restricted to see what that actually feels like? I have a few times, and I almost lost my temper over the message limit itself more than based on what my teammates were telling me in the chat. To give someone "messages over time" is an abomination. League is a tough game to multi task in, and when you have limited messages suddenly you're forced to condense content (which is wasted time in game spent typing) or simply not say certain things which actually might be important to convey to your teammates.

"Hey" *enter*
*uses ability*
"Let's try to get rift herald" *enter*
*uses ability*
"if I can kill my laner" *enter*

Turns into:

"Hey, let's try to get rift herald if I can kill my laner."

Now I'm forced to stand there missing trades and cs, which actually might be important, simply because I lost my temper in several games recently. Let's say, I even did use the first method, now I don't get another message for quite a long time since I used all of them... I need a gank, but I can't ask my Jungle for help because I no longer have access to messages.. What do you think happens? Now I'm helpless, getting the crap beat out of my by the enemy and I'm starting to be upset because my next message doesn't come for several minutes. These are just a couple of examples, the whole idea behind "limiting messages" is a bad strategy.

If Riot wants to truly obtain REAL DATA, they need to quit looking at their unrealistic dream of "reforming" players and completely remove ALL communication ability for the players who are consistently being aggressive with communication. If a player cannot ping, see any other players talking, or talk in the chat, the only thing they will be capable of doing is focusing on themselves. 

Sure, you cannot remove all forms of trolling.. some people just want to watch the world burn. They'll get angry at a failed gank and blow their summoner spells or ultimate for no reason, or even begin intentionally feeding, but to me that's the level where players deserve to be banned. Player's shouldn't be banned for having poor communication skills. Immigrants, Tourists, and Citizens aren't kicked out of the United States simply because they cannot speak English, nor do they get arrested for swearing in public (I can't speak for all countries). Communication in A GAME (yes, A GAME, a form of entertainment) should not be a focal point for removing players. Abusing the systems in place (aka feeding, trolling, cheating, etc.), should be the only reason an account is ever permanently banned.

I have never received any form of punishment in this game, but that's not to say I've never gotten angry at people, oh no. However, I don't use chat to abuse or harass other players, instead keeping it focused on mostly gameplay related stuff or stuff like "gj" whenever a successful play is made. What I do instead is just yell and rage at the screen to vent my anger and frustration. Now I understand that that's not an option for everyone, hence why I suggest that those people hit a pillow or squeeze a stress ball-something that's not raging at people via chat.

Also, the purpose of chat restrictions is to encourage people to use chat for mostly gameplay related things such as "fid flashless" rather than get into a heated argument (or worse a flame war) with someone else. While I do get what you're saying about the annoyance about having limited messages to send at any given time (especially in situations like your example), it does beg the question though that if one is getting chat restricted allot then perhaps that means that there's a problem with that particular player rather than the nature of chat restrictions themselves.

> If Riot wants to truly obtain REAL DATA, they need to quit looking at their unrealistic dream of "reforming" players and completely remove ALL communication ability for the players who are consistently being aggressive with communication. If a player cannot ping, see any other players talking, or talk in the chat, the only thing they will be capable of doing is focusing on themselves. 

Some people reform, some don't. At least Riot is giving people the opportunity to reform when most other companies would just outright ban players right away. For some people a simple reminder/notice that "hey, your behavior has been pretty unsportsmanlike lately. Try taking a break to regroup and cool off" is all it takes to get them [back] on the right track. As for removing all forms of communication in a game like this I feel that's a bad idea. Besides, Riot has stated numerous times in the past that they will not remove features just because some players would abuse them to be jerks to others, opting instead to remove the jerks abusing said features.
 
> Sure, you cannot remove all forms of trolling.. some people just want to watch the world burn. They'll get angry at a failed gank and blow their summoner spells or ultimate for no reason, or even begin intentionally feeding, but to me that's the level where players deserve to be banned. Communication in A GAME (yes, A GAME, a form of entertainment) should not be a focal point for removing players. Abusing the systems in place (aka feeding, trolling, cheating, etc.), should be the only reason an account is ever permanently banned.

Technically Riot is doing exactly what you think they should be doing, removing players who frequently abuse the systems in place, with chat being one such system.

Also from my experience when it comes to chat related offenses people are only punished for fighting with and harassing people, not necessarily for miscommunication. You're right in that this is a game and like all games it's meant to be enjoyed. You know what's not enjoyable? Having to deal with and listen to people argue, fight with and harass others. Why should Riot allow someone to keep playing when they have repeatedly proven that they aren't gonna change their behavior enough to consistently interact with others in a neutral or positive manner even if they've spent money on the game? To quote [Kei143](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/mmh6PidR-the-dreaded-downvoteers-in-this-discussion-board?comment=0001000100000000000100000004): 

>When Riot permabans someone, their philosophy is "the chances of this guy reforming isn't a whole lot, we'd rather not have him in the game". Thus in their eyes, they have already written off the toxic player as a paying client.

>From a business standpoint, do they want to remove the toxic guy who has spent $500 but is causing a negative environment for 4-9 other players in every game? Those non-toxics are also spending $500 and probably will spend more, promote the game more when they are enjoying the game AND they won't cause a negative environment.

>I personally think it is a fine argument to protect the ones that are paying money and aren't toxic rather than protecting the ones that may pay the same amount but are toxic.

Yes Riot can't stop people from making new accounts but the chronic misbehavers will eventually find that their newer accounts also punished as well if they continue to misbehave.

I keep seeing players saying they were banned for telling people to ward, then they post their logs and it is always like "Holy fuck, you piece of shit, why don't you ward %%%?" or something like that.

Why is being given temp bans and being told not to use that language so triggering? I highly doubt one would use that language at your job or in public on a regular basis... so why do people think they should say those things to others here?
Snowflakes? You mean people crying about their chat restriction?
Do you say the same shit you say online to people irl?
Is your goal to force people to use the mute button or to win a game?

Riot going ham with the bans is EXACTLY what the game needs in terms of Player Behavior.

This doesn´t have anything to do with Riot wanting to make the game for kids, but rather Riot telling everyone in a very polite way to not be assholes.

Internet, video games, it doesn´t matter. It´s not an excuse to be an asshole. You want people to ward?

Ping the place. Send in chat 'ward pls' and done.

Meanwhile most people are complaining about riot not banning enough.

Sounds like you got banhammered, and your attitude suggests why.

Basic respect and mature behavior is expected in public and on the internet, if you cant handle that, you have no right to whine about others being immature..

I know that a coping mechanism for trash is to project and say everyone else is just as bad as they are, but really, the people who get banned are a tiny fraction of the playerbase. Only a couple percent.
Its a free 2 play game, Riot can do whatever the want. At the expense of losing their core player base XD.
